This is the one picture I have of the inside:

image1536×2048 518 KB

It’s obviously pretty blurry, and it doesn’t have a picture of the daughter board (where the actual driver chip is). But I can tell that it’s STM32 of some kind. I’ll try to get more pics tonight.

It is a STM32F302

I think it is the CC model but I can’t read my photo that clearly.

Here are some pictures of a new SparkMax controller. The main mcu is indeed the STM32F302 CCT6 and the driver is a TI DRV8320S.

2017_0326_193940_0061920×1440 285 KB

2017_0326_193817_0021920×1440 369 KB

2017_0326_193833_0031920×1440 277 KB

I think so - and there’s some sort of thin adhesive pad on top of the main chips (the whit-ish squares). Made it a little tricky to get a good image.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2023-05-17T02:31:10.220Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":498,"readers_count":497,"score":109.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":437180,"topic_slug":"what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":1082,"username":"sanddrag","name":"sanddrag","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c68b51/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53412,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max/437180/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3208072,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-17T02:37:31.522Z","cooked":"

The STM32F302 is a really nice chip. STM makes it easy (relative) to program.

CAN built in
Motor control libraries included
Great GPIO

Really cool chipset.

The Falcon 500 uses some sort of dsPIC33 chip I think. That’s also a great chip with built in motor control and CAN, however it’s automotive grade and popular in that space so i think it was hit hard by the chip shortage

what specification would make the falcon’s chip “automotive grade” in comparison?

It is a different temperature rating plus stress testing of the design to some automotive standards. This brief article gives a short overview.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2023-05-17T05:07:31.485Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":420,"readers_count":419,"score":129.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437180,"topic_slug":"what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.everythingrf.com/community/what-is-aec-q100-qualification","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"What is AEC-Q100 Qualification? - everything RF","clicks":17}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55833,"username":"unident","name":"Nicholas ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unident/{size}/188354_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max/437180/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3208127,"name":"Ken Pontbriant","username":"electroken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/electroken/{size}/160387_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-17T10:02:47.615Z","cooked":"

If that’s flux, it’s a crapload of it and I would expect to see it everywhere. My guess is that we’re seeing a selectively applied conformal coating on parts with small pin pitches to protect from moisture or debris and limit dendritic growth.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2023-05-17T10:02:47.615Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":391,"readers_count":390,"score":198.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437180,"topic_slug":"what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max","display_username":"Ken Pontbriant","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":1082,"username":"sanddrag","name":"sanddrag","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c68b51/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17612,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 230 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max/437180/11","custom_user_title":"FRC 230 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3208241,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-17T16:52:30.288Z","cooked":"
Dan:

some sort of thin adhesive pad on top of the main chips

IIRC, this material is to assist with heat transfer to/through the case.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2023-05-17T16:52:30.288Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":330,"readers_count":329,"score":81.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437180,"topic_slug":"what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-chip-is-in-the-spark-max/437180/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3208243,"name":"Mike","username":"Mike_RT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_rt/{size}/186553_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-17T16:54:17.188Z","cooked":"

Is that a debug interface I see on the right side?

It’s not a thermal pad - the chips are not in contact with any surface (just in open air).

Are you talking about the button or ports? The button is brake/coast mode (for when you aren’t using CAN). I believe the ports may be for custom circuits but I have no idea other than guesses.

It is a thermal Pad. Different chips need to be heat sunk differently, that specific MOSFET package heat sinks into the bottom of the chip through the PCB.

sanddrag:

Is that flux residue I’m seeing? I’ve never cracked one open.

Dan:

I think so - and there’s some sort of thin adhesive pad on top of the main chips (the whit-ish squares). Made it a little tricky to get a good image.

What you see in this image is conformal coating not flux residue. The pads are for conduction isolation to the metal case while still having good thermal conductivity.
